abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Water Supply
            Project was unsatisfactory. The project failed to provide
            the availability of safe potable water in rural settlements,
            and improve health; instead, it achieved barely a sixth of
            the targeted area. The development of communal
            responsibility for facilities, was only partially achieved,
            because the Government failed to delegate management of the
            water facilities to the communes. Finally, although cost
            recovery schemes were established, they remain inadequate to
            serve operation, maintenance, and, renewal costs. Key
            lessons suggest that, in situations dealing with
            post-conflict assistance - and although the Bank was
            flexible enough through the project restructuring process -
            this process should properly review the development
            objectives, and components, since, the assessment of
            institutional, and, policy reform targets, should be given
            special attention in project reformulation. Although the
            project was innovative, with multiple donors, and wide
            coverage, this design was too complex. This proved negative
            for the final beneficiaries, since donor funds - largely for
            civil works - were discontinued due to the country
            instability. Furthermore, co-financing may largely limit
            implementation, particularly in post-conflict situations,
            thus financing should be simple, with possibly, supplemental
            credits to ease financing.

18157805.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Rural policies and institutions,Decentralization

abstracts.cdata!:
This second project within the water
            supply sector aims to provide Rwandans with safe water
            within reasonable distances from their homes. Specifically,
            it aims to strengthen institutions involved in the water
            supply subsector, establish cost recovery mechanisms  for
            safe water and support a program to rehabilitate rural water
            supply systems.  To this end, the project intends to provide
            (a) an institutional component with technical assistance and
            training, to reinforce the General Directorate of Water
            (GDW), as well as the communes and the users associations.
            It also includes (b) a national program utilising "line
            of credit financing" for rehabilitation, operation and
            maintenance of existing rural water supply systems
            throughout the country. The first-year work program is
            expected to be ready about the time of credit effectiveness.
            The communes will carry out the sub-projects pertaining to
            their communities, with assistance from local
            non-governmental organizations. Lastly, the project involves
            (c) specific investments for the rehabilitation and
            expansion of seven water supply systems in the Lava Region
            (North-West Rwanda).  Benefits under the proposed project
            are expected to result in improvements in the productivity
            and well-being of the rural population throughout Rwanda.
